abstract: So far, prosecutors and regulators have come up woefully short given their stated ambitions to bring landmark cases against financial executives.
snippet: So far, prosecutors and regulators have come up woefully short given their stated ambitions to bring landmark cases against financial executives.
lead_paragraph: Why should Wall Street care about a medieval English archbishop? Because as prosecutors fail to come up with strong legal cases against the bankers and traders who supposedly ran the financial industry into the ground, it’s a good bet they will soon resort to a modern-day variation of the prosecutorial technique perfected by King Henry VII’s chancellor — the so-called Morton’s fork.

headline.main: Plenty of Ways to Punish Wall Street
headline.print_headline: Plenty of Ways to Punish Wall Street

byline.original: By Rob Cox and Richard Beales

abstract: With Toyota’s battered reputation and Tesla Motors’ planned I.P.O. in need of some buzz, the electric partnership between the carmakers ought to bear fruit both in today and in the future, Reuters Breakingviews says.
snippet: With Toyota’s battered reputation and Tesla Motors’ planned I.P.O. in need of some buzz, the electric partnership between the carmakers ought to bear fruit both in today and in the future, Reuters Breakingviews says.
lead_paragraph: The Toyota Prius is sometimes known as the Pious. The pioneering but earnest vehicle could do with an injection of supercar glamour from Tesla Motors’ Roadster, and vice versa from a practicality standpoint, Reuters Breakingviews says.
